support_summary: Ubiquilin 2 (UBQLN2) is genetically linked to ALS and is involved in protein degradation pathways. It directly binds to the C-terminal region of TDP-43, facilitating its clearance through both the proteasome and autophagy, and is found in pathological TDP-43 inclusions.

functions.cellular_process: Ubiquilin-2 (UBQLN2) is an adaptor protein that recognizes, binds to, and facilitates the clearance of both soluble and aggregated forms of TDP-43. It shuttles ubiquitinated TDP-43 to the proteasome for degradation and is also involved in the maturation of autophagosomes.
functions.effect_description: UBQLN2 enhances the degradation of full-length TDP-43 and its toxic C-terminal fragments, thereby reducing their pathological accumulation in the cell.
biological_consequence: Soluble misfolded TDP-43 → UBQLN2 recognizes and binds ubiquitinated TDP-43 → UBQLN2 shuttles TDP-43 to the 26S proteasome → Proteasomal degradation of TDP-43
ALS/FTD-linked UBQLN2 mutations → Impaired TDP-43 delivery to proteasome/autophagosome → Accumulation of insoluble TDP-43 aggregates → Formation of cytotoxic inclusions → Motor neuron degeneration
specific_effects: UBQLN2 binds with high affinity to the C-terminal region of TDP-43.
Overexpression of UBQLN2 significantly reduces the levels of both full-length and C-terminal fragments of TDP-43 in cells.
Mutations in UBQLN2 are associated with ALS and FTD, and the mutant protein is found in TDP-43 positive inclusions.
UBQLN2 is involved in both proteasomal degradation and the maturation of autophagosomes.
Co-expression of wild-type human TDP-43 exacerbates UBQLN2-mediated neurodegeneration in C. elegans.

evidence.paper_title: Human Ubiquilin 2 and TDP-43 copathology drives neurodegeneration in transgenic Caenorhabditis elegans
evidence.relevant_quote: co-expression of wild-type human TDP-43 exacerbates UBQLN2 deficits. This model of UBQLN2-mediated neurodegeneration may be useful for further mechanistic investigation...
